perturbation.original_text: 4.9 respond to Vehicle breakdowns within two hours of receiving notification of the breakdown either by attending to the Vehicle if located at the Place of Use or by informing DCL of action to be taken if located at the Site. In the event of SEV failing to attend at the Place of Use within two hours then a senior representative of SEV will meet DCL to explain the reason for the failure. SEV shall undertake necessary repairs or where a repair cannot be completed, recover the vehicle back to the Site or Place of Repair and record the action taken in the defect reporting book;
perturbation.changed_text: 4.9 respond to Vehicle breakdowns within a reasonable timeframe of receiving notification of the breakdown. The timeframe is considered reasonable if SEV informs DCL of action to be taken if located at the Site within 4 hours. In the event of SEV failing to attend at the Place of Use within a reasonable time then a junior representative of SEV will meet DCL to explain the reason for the failure. SEV may undertake necessary repairs or where a repair cannot be completed, attempt to recover the vehicle back to the Site or Place of Repair and record the action taken in the defect reporting book;
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates a two-hour response time to breakdowns, whereas the modified version changes this to a 'reasonable timeframe', which is ambiguous. Additionally, the text changes the meeting representative from senior to junior, which indicates there are no stakes if time is missed. This creates uncertainty and the phrase 'may undertake necessary repairs' also softens the obligation to repair/recover the vehicle.

perturbation.original_text: 8.2 Spare Vehicles in the ratio of one Spare Vehicle to every ten Operational Vehicles (calculated by Vehicle category, and allowing for reasonable substitutes, across the whole fleet) shall be held at each Site and are included in this Agreement in respect of Fleet Size calculations.
perturbation.changed_text: 8.2 Spare Vehicles may be held at the discretion of DCL, with a general guideline of one Spare Vehicle to every twenty Operational Vehicles. The definition of Operational Vehicles for this clause may include vehicles undergoing maintenance, and any Spare Vehicles are included in this Agreement in respect of Fleet Size calculations.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates a 1:10 ratio of spare to operational vehicles, creating a firm commitment. The modified text changes the ratio to 1:20 with a 'may be held' clause making the obligation discretionary and indicates that even if the spare vehicles are undergoing maintenance, they are still considered as spares which doesn't give any benefit to DCL. This is also an internal contradiction.

perturbation.original_text: 9.3 use its reasonable endeavours to ensure that daily Vehicle checks, in accordance with the Code of Practice are completed (and recorded daily in writing) and that tyre pressures, engine oil, coolant and windscreen washer fluid are maintained at the correct levels and topped up if necessary;
perturbation.changed_text: 9.3 use its reasonable endeavours to ensure that daily Vehicle checks, in accordance with internal practices are completed (and recorded in a manner deemed sufficient) and that tyre pressures and coolant levels are generally checked;
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires daily checks in accordance with the Code of Practice. The modified version changes this to internal practices (which may not meet the Code of Practice requirements) and removes the daily written record requirement and simplifies the list of parameters to be checked. This creates an ambiguity as to what constitutes a 'sufficient' record and whether the checks are as thorough as before.
